title: The Importance of Writing an Ethical Will–for You and to Those You Love
body:
Marc Agronin (@MarcAgronin) is a geriatric psychiatrist at Miami Jewish Health and the author of “The End of Old Age: Living a Longer, More Purposeful Life” and “The Dementia Caregiver”
My colleague’s father recently got infected with the coronavirus and had to be rushed to the hospital. The move was abrupt and hectic, and left no time for any deep conversation with his wife and family as he was being taken out to the ambulance.
Countless moments like these have played out across the country over the past 10 months. And I’ve guided many patients and caregivers through conversations about what they would want to say to one another under such circumstances. But what could you possibly convey in a few moments--especially when your state of mind might be clouded?

There is no shortage of advice telling us to be prepared for an untimely illness or death by having legal documents in place--wills, health-care proxies and powers of attorney. But such paperwork is simply not sufficient to convey what our family means to us and what we mean to them.
